sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables users with limited vision, or no vision, to use the GNOME Desktop and associated applications. &app; provides the following functionality:

listitem.para: The screen reader enables non-visual access to standard applications in the desktop, using speech and Braille output.
The magnifier provides automated focus tracking and fullscreen magnification to aid low-vision users.

sect2.title: To Start Gnopernicus
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Applications Accessibility Screen Reader and Magnifier .
Execute the following command: gnopernicus
You can use the -d option to specify default settings.

sect2.title: When You Start Gnopernicus
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the Gnopernicus menu window appears:

textobject.phrase: Shows Gnopernicus menu window. Contains launchers for Startup Mode, Preferences, Default Preferences, Minimize, Help, About, and Quit.

sect2.para: The Gnopernicus menu window contains the following items:

listitem.para: The Startup Mode dialog enables you to choose the functionality that you want &app; to provide when you launch the application. You can use the dialog to apply functionality changes while you are using the application.
Click on this item to adjust the settings for speech output, magnifier behavior, Braille output, Braille monitor, mouse behavior, and key mapping.
Click on this item at any time to load the default settings for &app;.
Click on this item to minimize the Gnopernicus menu window.
Click on this item to open the Help manual for &app;.
Click on this item to read developer information about the &app; application.
Click on this item to exit &app; at any time.

sect2.title: To Activate Speech Output
sect2.para: Speech output is normally active by default when &app; starts. However, if there is no speech output, click on Startup Mode in the &app; menu window, then select the Speech option in the Startup Mode dialog.
Some useful assigned actions on the numeric keypad that you can use to work with the Speech output feature are as follows:

entry.para: Pause or continue reading a large chunk of text.
Repeat the last utterance. To spell out characters, press CtrlLeft Arrow.
Provide speech output of the complete contents of a window through the hierarchy of the contents. This is called a logical review.
Provide speech output of the complete contents of a window flattening the hierarchy in a left-to-right top-to-bottom way. This is called a spatial review.

sect2.para: For information about how to use different keypad layers, see .

sect2.title: To Activate Braille Output
sect2.para: Click on Startup Mode in the &app; menu window, then select the Braille option in the Startup Mode dialog. The application translates all system output to Braille for display on a Braille device.

sect2.title: To Start the Magnifier
sect2.para: Click on Startup Mode in the &app; menu window, then select the Magnifier option in the Startup Mode dialog.

When the magnifier is activated, half of the screen appears normal size and the other half of the screen is magnified. The location of the cursor on the normal-size screen is indicated by a mobile cross-hair on the magnified part of the screen.

sect2.title: To Start the Braille Monitor
sect2.para: You can start Braille Monitor in the following ways:

listitem.para: Click on Startup Mode, then select the Braille Monitor option.
Execute the following command: /usr/libexec/brlmonitor

You can specify the following options with the brlmonitor command:
[-column | -c]
Number of columns on the display
[-line | -l]
Number of lines on the display
[-mode | -m]
Specifies the font: [normal]
[-port | -p]
UDP port number

sect2.para: The purpose of the Braille Monitor is to show you the output that is sent to a Braille device. You can view the output in standard text format, Braille format, or both formats in the Braille Monitor.

sect2.title: To Start Gnopernicus in Minimized Mode
sect2.para: You can start &app; with the main window minimized, but you can still use the &app; functions. To do this, click on Startup Mode in the &app; menu window, then select the Start minimized option.

sect2.title: Command Mapping With Layer Keys
sect2.para: &app; functions are mapped onto keys on the numeric keypad. Because the number of keys on the numeric keypad is limited, the functions are assigned in layers. Any key can have multiple functions, depending on which layer is active. You can use the assigned layers of the &app; numeric keypad to work with the different functional areas of the application. The numeric keypad codes are written as follows:
LayernnKeynn
Explanation:

entry.para: Represents the number of the keypad layer.

sect3.title: To Switch Between Numeric Keypad Layers
sect3.para: To switch between numeric keypad layers, perform the following actions:

listitem.para: Press the Num Lock key to switch on Num Lock.
Press the 0 key on the numeric keypad.

Press the key on the numeric keypad that corresponds to the layer you want to activate. See for more information about which keys are assigned to each layer. You must perform this action within five seconds of the first action. If you do not press the layer number within five seconds, then &app; does not change the current layer.

sect3.title: To Modify Defined Layer Keys
sect3.para: To modify layer keys that are already defined, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click on Command Mapping in the &app; Preferences menu window.
Open the Layers tab in the Command Mapping dialog.
Select the layer code you want to modify.
Click Modify.
Make your modifications.
Click OK.

sect3.title: To Define Your Own Keyboard Shortcuts
sect3.para: To assign your own keyboard shortcuts for commands, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click on Command Mapping in the &app; Preferences menu window.
Open the User defined tab in the Command Mapping dialog.
Click Add. The Add User Defined Key dialog is displayed.
Select the modifier key that you want to use from the Modifier keys options.
Select the key that you want to use from the Key drop-down list.
Click OK. The Commands List dialog is displayed.
Select the command that you want to associate with the new layer key from the Commands list.
Click OK.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To open the Preferences menu window, click on Preferences in the &app; menu window.

sect2.title: Speech Preferences
sect2.para: Click on Speech in the Preferences window to open the Speech Preferences dialog. The Speech Preferences dialog contains the following options to enable you to modify the speech output:

listitem.para: Select one of the following options to determine how much of the punctuation in text the reader outputs:
The reader does not output any punctuation.
The reader outputs the following punctuation marks: < > ( ) { } * − + =
The reader outputs the following punctuation marks: < > ( ) { } * − + = , " '
Select one of the following options to determine the speech feedback that you receive as you type text:
Receive speech feedback after every character that you type.
Receive speech feedback after every word that you type.
Disable speech feedback when you are typing text.

Select this option to hear the total number of repeated characters rather than receive speech feedback after each character. For example, if the text includes = = =, the reader outputs the text as “three equals” instead of “equals equals equals”.
Select this option to hear the name of each modifier key that you press.
Select this option to hear the name of each navigation key that you press.
Select this option to hear speech feedback every time that you press the spacebar.

Select this option to use a dictionary of replacement words or phrases. To view the dictionary, click on the Dictionary button. The dictionary contains a list words and replacement words. For example, if the user types “USA”, the reader outputs the replacement word “United States of America”.
To add words to the dictionary, click Add. To modify words in the dictionary, select the word, then click Modify. To remove words from the dictionary, select the word, then click Remove.
To modify the speaker, volume, rate, or pitch settings, click on the Voices button. The Voices dialog is displayed. See for more information.

sect3.title: Voice Preferences
sect3.para: The Voices dialog contains the following options:

listitem.para: This list box lists the voices that are currently configured for different types of system output.
Click this button to add a new voice to the voices list.
Click this button to modify an existing voice. You must first select the voice that you want to modify, then click Modify.
Click this button to remove an existing voice. You must first select the voice that you want to remove, then click Remove.
Click this button to test how a voice sounds.
Click this button to assign absolute values to the voice settings.
Click this button to assign relative values to the voice settings.

sect2.title: Braille Preferences
sect2.para: Click on Braille in the Preferences window to open the Braille Preferences dialog. The Braille Preferences dialog contains the following options:

listitem.para: Braille Device
Translation Table
Braille Style
Cursor Preferences
Braille Key Mapping
Use this drop-down list to select the type of Braille device that you are using.
Use this spin box to select the port number to which the Braille device is connected.

sect3.title: Translation Table Preferences
sect3.para: Use this list box to select the language from which the Braille device is translating.

sect3.title: Braille Style Preferences
sect3.para: &app; can display 6-dot or 8-dot Braille code. Select one of the following options:

sect3.title: Cursor Preferences
sect3.para: Select one of the following options to determine how &app; displays the cursor in Braille:

listitem.para: Display a full-cell cursor. &app; uses all of the dots in the cell.
Display an underlined cursor. &app; uses dots 7 and 8 only.
Do not display a cursor.

sect3.title: Braille Key Mapping Preferences
sect3.para: The Braille Display Key Mapping dialog contains three tabbed sections as follows:

sect4.title: Position Sensors and Optical Sensors
sect4.para: Braille devices can contain position or optical sensors that the user can activate to perform an action. The Position Sensors and Optical Sensors tabbed sections enable you to select the action that the system performs when a user activates a position sensor or an optical sensor. The Position Sensors and Optical Sensors tabbed sections contain the same options. You can select one of the following options for each sensor type:

para.guilabel: Move mouse and click left or right

listitem.para: This option is not available on the Optical Sensors tabbed section.

sect4.title: Braille Keys
sect4.para: The Braille Keys tabbed section contains a list of the predefined Braille device keys that are assigned to commands.
To add a new Braille key to the list, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click Add in the Braille Keys tabbed section.
Select a command from the Commands list.
Select the Braille device keys that you want to associate with the command from the Device key drop-down list.
Click OK.

sect4.para: To modify the command that is associated with a Braille device key, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the entry in the Braille Keys tabbed section.
Click Modify.
Select a command from the Commands list.
Click OK.

sect4.para: To delete a Braille key from the list, select the entry, then click Remove.

sect2.para: Click on Magnifier in the Preferences window to open the Magnifier Preferences dialog. The Magnifier Preferences dialog contains the following options:

Click on the color selector button to display the color selector dialog and select a color for the pointer.

Click on the color selector button to display the color selector dialog and select a color for the cross-hair.

This list box lists the groups of magnification settings that are available. To add a group of magnification settings, click Add/Modify. The Zoomer Options dialog is displayed. See for more information.
To remove a group of magnification settings, select the group, then click Remove.
